text: Darkness. The sound of a radio and pots and pans clanging fades in. Caden, 40, opens his eyes in bed, and groggily looks at himself in the bureau mirror. The bedside clock reads 7:45.
Adele, 40, in t-shirt and sweats, mixes a bowl of instant oatmeal, puts it in the microwave.
... a Labor Day luncheon today --
Mommy! Done! -- at Stuckey Hall --
Okay!-- in downtown Schenectady -- Adele leaves the kitchen. Caden, also 40, enters as she's leaving. He's dressed in a ratty terrycloth robe.
Morning. Morning. Tried not to wake you.
Thanks. You didn't. I was just -- As Caden's voice goes under, we follow Adele into --
Olive, 4, sits on the toilet. Adele enters, rips some toi paper off the roll and proceeds to wipe Olive. The phone rings in the kitchen.
Caden, could you get that? It's Maria. I don't want to.
Ugh. Caden! (looks at bright green smear on toilet paper) That's weird. The phone stops ringing.
Is something wrong with my poop? (CONTINUED)
No, honey. It's just green.Hi, it's me. Where are you? Maybe you ate somethingI'll try you on your cell. green.
I didn't! What's wrong with me?! A cellphone rings in the other room.
Honey, I have to get this. You're going to be fine.
But, Mommy -- Adele runs into --
She rifles through her purse, grabs her cellphone, answer
Hey. (LAUGHING)
Oh, wiping Olive's ass. You? Caden is pouring himself a cup of coffee. He sips it and stares out the window. It's raining.
You're kidding! Holy fuck! Caden exits with his coffee, annoyed about the phone call
I don't feel well.
Caden passes the bathroom. Olive is staring into the toil bowl. Adele can be heard chatting in the background.
Daddy, my poop is green. Caden enters the bathroom, looks into the bowl at the gre feces and smeared toilet paper. He seems freaked out.
Am I going to be okay? (CONTINUED)
Of course, honey.
Did you have green poop when you were little?
I'm sure I did, honey. Am I going to die?
Of course not. You probablyI didn't! I didn't eat ate something -- green!
It'll be fine, sweetie. I'll be back in a minute.
(CALLING)
Is poop alive?

Caden steps out the front door in his bare feet and hurri down the driveway in the rain. He picks up the newspaper, pulls the mail from the box. As he heads back inside, he flips through the mail. There's a magazine called Attendi to your Illness addressed to Caden. A diseased person on cover. Across the street a gaunt man watches Caden, unsee
Caden sits at the kitchen table with his coffee, reading paper, dated Friday, October 14, 2005.
All right, baby. See you then. Adele clicks off her cellphone.
Harold Pinter died!
Yeah? Huh. Well, he wasOh wait. He won the Nobel old, right?Prize. Good for him.
Mom! (CONTINUED)
What?!Do you need to come look at my poop again?!
No, Olive, it's fine. JustWhat if it's alive? What if flush.I kill it? It's green! Like plants!
It's not alive, honey.God, remember that production of The Dumbwaiter I did at Albanyfest? The toilet is flushed.
Everything's alive. Everything grows big. That's how you know. Olive enters.
I have your oatmeal, honey.
I want peanut butter and jelly.
Olive, c'mon. You told me I don't want oatmeal. oatmeal. This isn't a restaurant. Adele growls, grabs the oatmeal, dumps it in the sink.
Sorry, Mommy! I'm sorry!(looking at paper) They found Avian flu in Turkey. In the country Turkey not turkeys. It's in chickens. Adele is making a peanut butter sandwich for Olive.
Can I watch TV till school? Caden clicks the remote for Olive and goes back to his pa A cartoon cow talks to a cartoon sheep. (CONTINUED)

There is a secret, something at play under the surface, growing like an invisible virus of thought. The sheep nods. Caden pours himself some more coffee, ope the milk carton to pour some in, then sniffs at the spout He checks the date on the carton. It's October 20.
Man. Milk's expired. Jesus. But you are being changed by it. Second by second. Every breath counts off time. Caden goes back to his paper. Adele puts a peanut butter sandwich in front of Olive.
Here. Now you better eat this.
I will. The first black graduate of the University of Alabama died. Vivian Malone Jones. Stroke. Only 63. Adele stares out the window at the rain.
Caden is in the dentist's chair, a bloody bib around his neck. The dentist, in surgical mask, probes his open mout calls out numbers to an assistant, who records them.
(to Caden) Family coming for Thanksgiving?

Caden shaves. A faucet explodes and smacks him in the forehead. He is sent staggering backwards with a yelp, in the far wall, his razor flying and blood pouring from a jagged cut above his right eyebrow. Off-screen, we hear t pounding footsteps of someone running toward us. Half of Caden's face is covered with shaving cream. Rivulets of blood intermingle with it. Water shoots out where the tap was, spraying the mirror, which is spattered with blood. Adele, dressed in heavily paint-splattered clothes, hurri in and takes in the scene: the wet, the mess, the blood. (CONTINUED)
Jesus! Caden! What the fuck -- ?! Olive, in a nightgown, stands quietly in the doorway, her curled toes clenched. She holds a large stuffed owl.
Um. I was shaving and -- My God! Jesus! Look at your head! Dumbly, Caden tries to look up at his forehead, then squi nervously at himself in the mirror.
(to Olive) Honey, don't look. Olive turns around.
Put pressure. Press. Press!
Do I press above or below it?

I don't know! Just... both! Caden sits on the toilet, presses a towel to his head. Ad squats, goes into a spasmodic coughing fit, finishes, ope the cabinet under the sink, pushes her arm through bottle cleaning products, old sponges, old toothbrushes, toilet paper rolls and other junk to the shut-off valves.
I can't turn it! It's gonna flood! Olive hugs the owl tightly and it speaks.
Whooo. Whooo. Whooo areI can't -- Oh wait, got it! you? Adele turns off the water. Olive looks back into the room
Mommy, Daddy has blood.
Caden sits on a metal table. The room has some meager Christmas ornaments. A doctor stitches Caden's forehead. (CONTINUED)
Caden squints into the bright light the doctor uses to se his work. In the background we hear another patient.
(CRYING)
Please, please, please... Caden sees a nurse shoving a tube far up into a man's nos Another nurse wipes away the blood leaking out his nostri
Will there be a scar?
Probably. It looks like a mudflap.
I prefer there not be a scar.
That fellow is annoying. He's in here every week. Like clockwork. The off-screen patient continues to whimper. The doctor finishes his work on Caden.
There. I think that should -- He looks at Caden's eyes, turns off the bright lamp and l again. He turns the lamp back on and looks once more.
What? The doctor feels Caden's pulse, then listens to his heart He presses hard against the glands in Caden's neck.
Changes in bowel movements?
A little more yellow than usual. What?
I'd like you to see an ophthalmologist.
A neurologist? (CONTINUED)
What? No, an ophthalmologist. I said, ophthalmologist.
Oh. The doctor stares blankly at Caden for a long moment, the looks suspiciously in Caden's ears.

Adele drives and coughs spasmodically. The car swerves a Caden has a bandaged head and a prescription in his hand. Olive, in her car seat, sings. Caden sees revelers in win coats and party hats outside a house. They blow noisemake and yell "happy new year!"
(SINGING)
It's a beautiful day and the sun is shining and yellow. And the world is too big to understand and today is Tuesday and -- (SPEAKING)
Mom, is today Tuesday?
No, it's Friday, honey.
(SINGING)
And today is Friday and... Olive's singing continues but goes under.
So what exactly did he say?
My pupils weren't properly dilating and, um, not doing the opposite ...
Constricting.
No. Yes. The bump to the head?
He doesn't know. Maybe. He said he doesn't think so. But maybe. But he doesn't know. But -- (CONTINUED)
Okay. I got it. Jesus.Sorry. I'm a little anxious.
Did you have to get a shot, Daddy?
No, honey. (to Adele) It's the start of something awful.
Do I have to get a shot?
What? No. Of course not. (pause, to Adele) This is really fucked timing.
Caden.
Sorry. Bad timing.Did you tell him I have green poop?
Remind me to call the (realizing) plumber, would you? I need aI have rehearsal! Fuck! to-do list. Caden!
Sorry.How many years till I have to get more shots?
Not for a long time, honey. Caden pulls out a cell phone and dials.
A million years?
Remember Dr. Woodman said Dad, what's a plumber? after the last vaccination --
He's the man who -- (CONTINUED)
Or woman, Dad.Right. He's the man or woman who fixes sinks and toilets and... do you know what pipes are?
No.
(into phone) Hey, Jim. I know. I'm sorry. I had an accident. No, I'm okay.
Like to smoke out of?

Different kind of pipe. (into phone) Just run lines. I'll be there soon. 'kay. (hangs up) Houses have pipes. They're, like, tubes and they're behind walls and under the floor everywhere and -- Olive begins to whimper in horror.
What's wrong, baby?
(hushed anxious whisper) Every-single-where?
It's okay. They just carry water to and from sinks and bathtubs and toilets. It's like in your body you have veins and ... um...
Capillaries.
And they're filled with blood. Olive is crying in earnest now.
I don't want blood. I have blood? (CONTINUED)
(to Caden) What are you doing? Jesus.
I'm trying to explain plumbing.
Well, stop it. (to Olive) It's okay, honey.
(WEEPING)
I don't want blood. Will it hurt? Will it hurt, Daddy?!
No, honey, you're fine.
I don't want blood! I don't (holding head) want blood! I don't wantI can't do this now. blood...
You don't have to worry, baby. You don't have blood.
Well, I don't think you should tell her she doesn't have blood.
Caden, stop it! Olive cries. Adele coughs. Caden stares out the window. I dark, but his pupils are pinpricks.
An ophthalmologist examines Caden's eyes. An eyeglass calendar on the wall is open to March 2006.
Thanks for getting me in right away. The doctor touches Caden's eye repeatedly with a small pr
Is it the bump to the head? (CONTINUED)
No. (writes in chart, then:) Could be. But I think we need to get you to a neurologist. Nothing urgent.
A neurologist?
Yes, a brain expert.
I know what a neurologist is. Fine. I just thought from the way you asked --
I thought maybe you said urologist. Why do I need to see a neurologist?
For a look-see. The eyes are part of the brain, after all.
That's not true, is it?
Why would I say it if it weren't true?
It just doesn't seem right.
Like morally correct? Or right as in accurate?
I'm not sure. Accurate, I guess.
Hmm. Interesting. The doctor writes in Caden's chart.

Caden sits in the almost empty theater. A few people with note-pads are scattered around. Centerstage, a 1948 Dodge Business Coupe. The car is surrounded by various rooms fr that period: a kitchen, bedrooms, etc. (CONTINUED)

Tom, the actor playing Willy Loman, stands center stage. Claire, the actress playing Linda Loman, sits in the set' bedroom. Davis, the actor playing Biff, lies on the top b of a bunk bed upstage. A fourth actor, playing Happy, lie the bottom bunk.
Willy, you coming up!!!!
Sssssh!!

Willy? Tom climbs in the car. CLAIRE (AS LINDA) (CONTAaaD) Willy? Answer me!...Willy! Tom starts the car and guns the engine. A brick wall off stage speeds into the car, accompanied by crashing and screeching sound effects. CLAIRE (AS LINDA) (CONTAaaD) No!!!
Pop!! The wall continues to be pulled past the car crashing int the rest of the set, knocking walls over, creating havoc. lamp post falls and hits Claire, knocking her over. (CONTINUED)
(running to stage)Yeah yeah, I'm fine. It's no Oh crap, Claire, are youbig deal. okay?
David, what's happening here? (looking back from seat) Sorry, Caden. Hold on. David runs on stage to deal with the mess.
It's too late in the game to be having these problems, David. (to Claire) You're sure you're okay?
God yes, it was funny.I know, Caden. I'm sorry. We'll get it. Tom emerges from the car, covered with stage blood. CADEN (CONTAaaD) Please. (to Tom) That was good, Tom.
Yeah? I was trying something different. I was crashing differently. Ambivalently.
I saw that. I like it. Caden meets Tom at the foot of the stage. Behind them a group of technicians are lifting the wall and trying to r set it. Claire primps in the bureau mirror.

Try to keep in mind that a young person playing Willy Loman thinks he's only pretending to be at the end of a life full of despair. But the tragedy is that we know that you, the young actor, will end up in this very place of desolation.
(taking this in) Okay. (CONTINUED)
Great. Let's try it again. (CALLING)
How long, David?
I think fifteen.
Why don't you get cleaned up, Tom, and we'll go again. Tom exits. Caden rubs his temples, then heads to the back the house, pulling out his cell phone. He exits the theat
Caden passes the box office. Hazel, 35, sits inside, read a novel. She looks up, smiles warmly, and waves.
I just heard the death of the salesman.
In more ways than one.
(COMPASSIONATELY)
Oh no. (THEN:)
(holding up cell phone) In search of elusive signal. (CONTINUED)
Signal's good here, oddly. She pats her lap in a friendly manner.
That is odd.
I know! Cell phones, they're crazy!
(chuckles)(back in her book) See you in a few. Yup.
Caden has the phone to his ear. He's squinting in the bri sunlight, pupils dilated. The gaunt man watches him unsee
Dr. Heshborg said I should see Dr. Scariano. My pupils don't work.
Hazel reads the first page of Swann's Way. The other volu of In Search of Lost Time are stacked neatly nearby. She looks up and sees Caden standing outside the box office window watching her.
I keep reading the first line. It's a good line, I think. But I don't know much about literature.
Maybe you should read the first line of another series of books.
I'm trying to better myself, Caden. Recommend me something. You're a genius; you must've read nearly a dozen books.
Exactly twelve. Have you read Kafka? (CONTINUED)
Um, I've read his name. A lot! I swear! (CONTINUED)
His whole name?
Okay, not his entire name. Heinz?
(LAUGHS)
You should read The Trial, maybe.
If you say so, I will. Can't wait till Wednesday. I'm so excited to see it.
I hope you like it.
It's pretty impossible that I won't, you know. I mean... She trails off, shrugs. They smile at each other. Caden exits. Hazel looks at her book, re-reads the first senten
Caden sits on the toilet. He finishes, looks in the bowl. His bowel movement is dark and loose.
Adele lies in bed asleep. Caden steps out of the bathroom and climbs into bed.
I think I have blood in my stool. Adele looks over, half asleep.
That stool in your office?
Caden and Adele sit across from Madeline, 40's, their therapist. Silence. Adele has a coughing fit. Then:
When I was pregnant with Olive...
What was it like? (CONTINUED)
Um... I don't know. Hopeful or something. Like something was going to change.
Something did, no?
Yes, of course. Yes. I mean... big time.
Maybe not as much as I had hoped. That's a terrible thing to say.
There are no terrible things to say in here. Only true and false.
I feel alone sometimes. I feel exhausted. Can I say something awful?
Yes. Please do.
I've fantasized about Caden dying and being able to start again. Guilt free. I know it's terrible.
Caden sits sadly on the steps; drinks coffee. He watches Hazel pulls into the parking lot, gets out of her car. Th gaunt man is behind the trash bin. She sits next to Caden
It's a nightmare in there.
The car crash?
Well... not only.
Sorry. So I'm reading The Trial.
Yeah? You like? (CONTINUED)
Love. I'm such an idiot for not knowing about this book. (conspiratorial whisper) It's famous, it turns out.
You're not an idiot. Pause.
Then you say, in fact, you're very bright, Hazel. And I love your eyes.
In fact, you're very bright, (playing charmed) Hazel. And I love your eyes. Oh, am I? Oh, do you? Oh, darling!
Then what do I say?
I can't say what then you say.
Why?
Cause it's dirty. A whistling noise turns their heads. In the distance a ma with an unopened parachute is plummeting.
Oh my God! Jesus! They watch as the man falls behind a building. A scream. screech of brakes.
He's gotta be dead. Right?
Caden enters. The plumber is working on the sink.
Go ahead. I've seen boy parts. SYN, NY - GOLDENROD REVISIONS - JULY 30, 2007 19.

The studio is a mess, the floor covered with paint. Adele in her paint-spattered clothing, works on a tiny canvas, inch square. She paints with a single-hair brush while looking through a magnifying glass. Caden pokes his head
Can I piss in your sink?

Um, yeah, I guess. Caden pisses in the sink in the corner of the studio. His urine is amber. He finishes and peeks over Adele's should through the magnifying glass at the painting. It's an amazingly detailed and angrily colored painting of a woma a state of profound despair, screaming to the heavens, wh standing in a field of flames.
It's gorgeous, Ad.
Thanks. How was rehearsal?
Awful. We have five hundred and sixty lighting cues. I don't know why I made it so complicated.
It's what you do.
Yeah. Anyway, we got through it. I think you'll be impressed.
Caden, listen, I'm really sorry. I just can't go tonight. (off his look) I'm sorry. I've got to get two canvases ready to ship. By tomorrow. I know it sucks.
But it's opening night.I know. I'm sorry. I would go if I could.
I have to get ready. (CONTINUED)
I'll go tomorrow! We'll makeI mean, I can't take a dump tomorrow like the premiere! in your sink! What am I supposed to do? I have to get ready!

The theater is full. Caden stands nervously in the back. The lights dim. Hazel looks back from her seat at Caden a mouths the word "yay." He smiles. The curtain rises on a dark stage. Tom, as Willy, gets out of the car parked cen stage and walks into the kitchen.
Oh boy, oh boy.
Willy!
It's all right, I came back.
Why? What happened? (PAUSE)
Did something happen, Willy?
No, nothing happened.
You didn't smash the car, did you?
I said nothing happened. Didn't you hear me?
Don't you feel well?
I'm tired to death. I couldn't make it. I just couldn't make it, Linda.
Where were you all day? You look terrible.
I got as far as a little above Yonkers. I stopped for a cup of coffee... maybe it was the coffee. (CONTINUED)
What?
I suddenly couldn't drive any more. The car kept going off onto the shoulder, y'know? The audience is rapt. Caden relaxes.
The cast party is in full swing. The opening was a succes Lots of drinking. Caden chats with Claire. Hazel watches from across the room.
(scrunching her nose) Ugh, I hated myself tonight. Plus I'm so bloated and enormous. (CONTINUED)
No. You looked great. You I thought Tom was amazing! were great. I was very pleased.
Yeah. Absolutely. (squints suddenly) Sorry. I have a bit of a headache.
(kisses his forehead) I just want to thank you for everything. You've been absolutely brilliant and it's going to be miserable going ahead without you.
I'll be around. I'll check in. She gets teary, gives him a kiss on the cheek.
God, I'm such a baby. She just looks at him and smiles and nods.
I'm going to get drunk, that's what.
Ok, Claire. She backs away and gets lost in the crowd. Caden massages his temples. Suddenly Hazel is next to him.
I figured I'd better get in fast.
Hey!
I loved it! And, by the way, Claire is trouble. And not terribly bright. Caden laughs.
Just wanted you to know the word on the street. (CONTINUED)
So you liked it?
Are you kidding? I cried for like fifteen minutes after. I loved every minute of it. Except Claire. I thought she was weak.
Easy on the eyes.
Oh, Caden, not you, too. What I want to know is why she started crying in her last monologue, right after she had the line, 'I can't cry for you Willy...'?
(LAUGHING)
She felt very strongly that it was right. They sip their drinks.
Where's el wife-o?
Had to work. Her Berlin show is in two weeks. We're going to spend like a month there.
Ah.
Ah.
Ah.
Choo!
Hooray! We've still got it! (PAUSE)
I'll miss you.
Yeah, me too. (CONTINUED)
You're going to miss you? Yeah, that's it.
(PAUSE)
Why do I like you so much? (CONTINUED)
I couldn't begin to guess.
(SIGHING)
Me neither. It must be that you're married. Do you get high, my friend?
Y'know. Sometimes.
You want to now? With me. In my car.
I don't know.Come on, it's a party.
I get kind of... something when I'm stoned.
What does something mean?
I don't know. Bothered?What does bothered mean?
Y'know... bothered. Horny.
And me with a station wagon and all. Could be dangerous.
(LAUGHING)
Yeah, it really could.
You're absolutely zero fun.
You know I wish I could.
Jesus, I like you. I'm going.
You're not staying for the reviews? (CONTINUED)
I know it's brilliant. I don't need some dope with elbow patches telling me. She smiles, gives him a hug, and heads toward the door.
Hazel drives down a dark street, crying. People watch her passing car from various windows. There's a run-over dog, lit by a streetlight, glistening on the side of the road.
Hazel studies the dog. It's a bloody, gutty mess, squashe flat. Against all odds, it's still alive. Its head is lolling. She bends down to pet it.
You're not going to make it, baby.
Hazel takes off her make-up, hair back in a clip. She watches herself blankly in the mirror, somewhat erased without eye make-up. The run-over dog is sleeping in a bo on the floor.

The party has thinned out. The remaining people are sitti around a table, drinking. Claire, next to Caden, rests he head, sleepily drunk, against his shoulder. Caden studies series of lumps under the skin of his arm.
What are you going to do now?
I'm going to Berlin for a month for my wife's show. Then I don't know.
I wish I was your wife or a wife or had a wife. Or was German even. I'm so lonely with none of those things. A man walks in with a bunch of newspapers. (CONTINUED)
Yay or nay?

Hazel gets out of her car and walks up to a neat little h on a street of neat little houses. Faint swirls of smoke escape from the windows. She rings the doorbell. The butt is hot; Hazel pulls her finger away.
The rooms are hazy. The realtor coughs a little. Hazel surveys the scene.
I've always loved this house.
Yes. It's a wonderful place.The truth is, I never really imagined I could afford it.
The sellers are very motivated now.
It's a scary decision. I never thought I'd buy a house alone. But, y'know, I'm 36, and I wonder what I'm really waiting for.
Home-buying is always scary.But I mean with the fire and all especially.
It's a good size though, twenty-two hundred square feet. Not including the partially-finished basement
I don't know. I'm thinking IIt's a perfect size for should go.someone alone.
I like it, I do. But I'm really concerned about dying in the fire.
It's a big decision, how one prefers to die. Would you like to meet my son? Derek? (CONTINUED)
Derek, 40 and scruffily handsome, appears around a corner
Hey, Mom.Derek's living in the basement since his divorce. If that's okay.
Caden enters. Adele sits at the table across from Maria, They are drunk and eating nachos.
Hey. Hey.
Hi, Caden. How'd it go?
Hi. It's late.
Maria came over to keep me company and we lost track. I'm sorry I missed the play. But I got everything done here. How'd it go?
We're a hit. Reviews are great. New York Times said it was brilliant to cast young actors as Willy and Linda.
Great. That's great, Caden! Good for you!
I'll see it tomorrow. Tonight! Adele and Maria laugh.
Jesus, it is late. Early!Can we get a ticket for I'd love to see it, too. Maria? Adele smiles.
Are you stoned? (CONTINUED)
A little. I don't know. Y'know? I mean, are you happy with it? (CONTINUED)
Yeah. Love to know what you think.
It doesn't matter what I think.
Absolutely! It's all about your artistic satisfaction, Caden.
Caden and Olive walk along. Caden holds a tax envelope. H face has pustules on it. The gaunt man follows.
What's wrong with your face, Daddy?
It's pustules. It's called sycosis. Spelled differently than psychosis, but it sounds the same.
I don't know what that means.
Well, there's two different kinds of psychosis. They're spelled differently. P-s-y is like if you're crazy and s-y is like these things on my face.
You could have both though.
I could. But I don't.
Okay, pretend we're fairies. I'm a girl fairy and my name is ... La-ru...lee. And you're a boy fairy and your name is Teeteree.
Ok.
What's my name again?
La-ru-lee. (CONTINUED)
No. I said ... La-ru-la...ay.
Caden and Olive are at the back of the long line of peopl
Pretend we fight each other. And I say stop hitting me or I'll die. And you say okay, but you're fibbing. And you hit me again.
Okay.
Okay. Let's go. Hit me. They pretend to hit each other. Olive makes hissing and roaring noises. She stops.
Okay. You have to stop hitting me now or I will die.
Okay. He stops.
No! Pretend you're fibbing! Remember? He mock hits her again. She falls.
Now I have to die. (BEAT)
Pretend you say you don't want me to die.
I don't want you to die.
(compassionate whisper) But I have to.
But I'll miss you. (CONTINUED)
I have to. And you'll have to wait a million years to see me again. Caden tears up at this and tries to conceal it.
And I'll be put in a box. And all I'll need is a tiny glass of water. And lots of -- tiny pieces of pizza. And the box will have wings, like an airplane.
Where will it take you?
(THINKS)
Home.

Performance in progress. There is now a cemetery on stage Linda, Biff, and other characters stand around a gravesit Caden sits in the audience between Adele and Maria and hi parents. He glances over at Adele's stony face. Maria is drunk and blurry.
Let's go, Mom.

I'll be with you in a minute. Go on, Charley. I want to, just a minute. The other characters exit the stage. CLAIRE (AS LINDA) (CONTAaaD) (talking to the grave) I never had a chance to say good- bye. Forgive me, dear. I can't cry. (begins to cry) I don't understand it; I can't cry. It seems to me that you're just on another trip. I keep expecting you. Willy, dear, why did you do it? I search and search and I search, and I can 't understand it, Willy. I made the last payment on the house today. Today, dear. And there'll be nobody home. We're free and clearAaA We're freeAaA We're freeAaA We're freeAaA (CONTINUED)

Caden, Adele, Maria, and his parents walk along. (CONTINUED)
I just --I don't know what it matters what I think.
I loved the story. So interesting.
Because your opinion is --It was good. It was well done. It was very ... successful.
Oh, I thought it was wonnnderful!
Why were the old people so young?

It was a choice, Dad. I'll Nothing. But nothing. explain later. (pause) (to Adele) I can't get excited about But? your restaging someone else's old play. There's nothing personal in it. CADENCADENAaaS FATHER I put my soul into thatI mean, they were younger thing. than their kids. That doesnAaat make sense.

Do you really believe that tripe? CADENCADENAaaS MOTHER Wow. It's not tripe. Jesus.I liked that the old people were so young. It was interesting. ADELE (CONTAaaD) Ok, fine. But it's not you. It's not anyone. It's not real.

People come out crying,Great. Be a fucking tool of saying their lives are suburban blue-hair regional changed and -- theater subscribers. But what are you leaving behind? You act as if you have forever to figure it out. (CONTINUED)
Why are you being like this? Adele has a coughing fit. (CONTINUED)
I'm not being like anything. Are you seeing someone else?
Is that your entire frame of reference for relationship problems?
